content:
Modern paganism is generally considered a religious movement, although the specific beliefs and practices of pagans can vary widely.

At its core, paganism is a pre-Christian religious tradition that emphasizes the worship of the natural world and the cycles of the seasons. Modern paganism draws on this ancient tradition, but also incorporates elements of other religious and spiritual practices, including Wicca, Druidism, Norse mythology, and shamanism.

Pagans may define their faith in a variety of ways, depending on their specific beliefs and practices. Some describe themselves as worshipers of nature, with a deep reverence for the earth, the moon, and the stars. Others may emphasize the use of mystical or magical practices, including divination, ritual, and spellcasting. Many pagans view their faith as a way to connect with the divine or with ancestral spirits, and may incorporate ancestor worship or veneration into their religious practices.

Despite these variations, many pagans share a commitment to living in harmony with nature, and to developing a greater sense of connection and meaning in their lives through their religious practices. They may also place a strong emphasis on community, and may gather together for seasonal celebrations, rituals, and other social events.
